definition: similar things come together (idiom); like draws like/Birds of a feather flock together.
thing/object/matter/abbr. for physics 物理
abbr. for Israel 以色列[Yi3 se4 lie4]
to use/by means of/according to/in order to/because of/at (a certain date or place)
kind/type/class/category/similar/like/to resemble
to congregate/to assemble/to mass/to gather together/to amass/to polymerize
Similar things group together, similar people fit together (idiom); Birds of a feather flock together.
pinyin: wu4 yi3 lei4 ju4 , ren2 yi3 qun2 fen1

sentences.english: Like attracts like , each creature loves his kind.
sentences.chinese: 物以類聚，各種生物都愛他的同類。

sentences.english: In the cosmos, there is a law that like attracts like.
sentences.chinese: 在宇宙中，有個規則叫物以類聚。

sentences.english: You’ll often see a pattern where like attracts like.
sentences.chinese: 你常會看到一種物以類聚的模式。

sentences.english: The saying that "birds of a feather flock together is very true."
sentences.chinese: 有句諺語叫“物以類聚人以羣分”是個真理。

sentences.english: B: I’m not surprised. Like attracts like.
sentences.chinese: 我不覺得意外，所謂物以類聚，人以羣分。

definition: to think highly of oneself (idiom); giving oneself airs/arrogant and self-important
to obstinately persist in going about things the wrong way (idiom)
lit. one body two sides (idiom)/fig. a situation with two sides to it
scholars tend to disparage one another (idiom)
fortunes rise and fall/times change
to disdain as beneath contempt (idiom)
survival of the fittest
philosophy of idealism, the doctrine that external reality is a product of consciousness
to comprehend (new things) by analogy
when things reach an extreme, they can only move in the opposite direction (idiom)
virtue has its rewards (idiom); one good turn deserves another
lit. you hoodwink me and I cheat you (idiom); fig. mutual deception/each tries to outwit the other/dog eats dog and devil take the hindmost
to show every possible consideration (idiom); meticulous care
man can conquer nature (idiom); human wisdom can prevail over nature
to use one's mouth (to say sth)
lit. heaven's law and earth's principle (idiom); fig. right and proper/right and unalterable/a matter of course
